channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Facebook finally explains its mysterious new wrist wearable
item.description: Will we be able to trust it with a new form of personal data? (Probably not.)

item.title: Apple bent its rules for Russia—and other countries will take note
item.description: Russian iPhone buyers soon to see prompts to install software developed in Russia.

item.title: Hackers are exploiting a server vulnerability with a severity of 9.8 out of 10
item.description: As if the mass-exploitation of Exchange servers wasn’t enough, now there’s BIG-IP.

item.title: Falcon & Winter Soldier series premiere: More of Disney+‘s slow-burn status quo
item.description: Disney+’s latest won’t unseat Justice League this weekend—but it belongs in your queue.

item.title: Zuckerberg: Facebook could be in “stronger position” after Apple tracking change
item.description: The change is expected to come with iOS 14.5 within just a few weeks.

item.title: Alkaline “Real Water” linked to liver failure in kids—and reports are rising
item.description: The FDA has warned not to drink or use the water.

item.title: LOL Garamond sux, say federal judges
item.description: Garamond—it’s just too small for the DC Circuit.

item.title: Victoria University of Wellington accidentally nukes files on all desktop PCs
item.description: “I always do that. I always mess up some mundane detail!"—Michael Bolton

item.title: Cricut fully abandons plans to make device owners pay subscription fee
item.description: The after-the-fact change was incredibly unpopular among device owners.

item.title: Amazon will spend $1 billion per year on NFL’s Thursday Night Football
item.description: New deal lets ESPN+, Peacock, Paramount+, and Tubi simulcast national games, too.

item.title: Under pressure, CDC drops school spacing to 3 ft in many classrooms
item.description: 3 ft enough for elementary; 6 ft best for middle, high schools if cases are high.

item.title: Chinese military restricts use of Teslas over security concerns
item.description: Employees at sensitive facilities have been asked not to drive Teslas to work.

item.title: Here are five questions we would ask the nominee for NASA administrator
item.description: “If we can’t do a rocket for $11.5 billion, we ought to close up shop.”

item.title: The economics of covering California’s water system with solar panels
item.description: Renewable power, less evaporation, lower maintenance, and more.

item.title: Mask up! How to choose and maintain the best masks for use against COVID-19 [Updated]
item.description: Finding masks that meet CDC and WHO guidelines is tough. We did the work for you.

item.title: Rocket Report: Pegasus booster will fly again, hacking SpaceX telemetry
item.description: “The RS-25 is a great program for us.”

item.title: Sherlock Holmes takes a back seat to street kids in The Irregulars trailer
item.description: New series modernizes Holmsian lore with diverse cast, supernatural elements.

item.title: NASA fired up its new rocket for 499.6 seconds on Thursday
item.description: The Green Run test may give NASA a green light to proceed with a launch.

item.title: “Expert” hackers used 11 0-days to infect Windows, iOS, and Android users
item.description: The breadth and abundance of exploits for unknown vulnerabilities sets group apart.

item.title: Real-world Supercross tracks have been influenced by the sport’s video game
item.description: Ars talks to the sport’s senior director of operations to learn about the whoops.

item.title: Sony acquires world’s largest fighting-game tourney series
item.description: Next online event, coincidentally, will only include PlayStation games.

item.title: AT&T lies about Calif. net neutrality law, claiming it bans “free data”
item.description: AT�T is angry that it must stop charging HBO Max rivals for data-cap exemptions.

item.title: Sony’s excellent WH-1000XM4 headphones are back down to their lowest price
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on the Nintendo Switch Lite, Dell monitors, and more.

item.title: One company wants to sell the feds location data from every car on Earth
item.description: Federal agencies already buy tons of user data; one vendor is now being sued.

item.title: The debate continues: ‘Oumuamua could be remnant of Pluto-like planet
item.description: Secret to at least one aspect of object’s unusual properties lies in solid nitrogen ice.

item.title: The next iPad Pro could have a Thunderbolt port
item.description: Report claims Mini LED is in the works, too.

item.title: Uber concedes UK drivers are workers—some drivers aren’t satisfied
item.description: Uber only wants to pay for “engaged time”—not time waiting for a new customer.

item.title: Chrome brings live-captioning to any web audio source
item.description: Machine-generated captions are great for podcasts, livestreams, and more.

item.title: New PSVR controllers suggest PS5 headset won’t need external sensors
item.description: Oculus Touch-style controllers bring DualSense-style haptic feedback, triggers.

item.title: Attackers are trying awfully hard to backdoor iOS developers’ Macs
item.description: XcodeSpy uses malicious Xcode project to install the EggShell backdoor.

item.title: Distraction, not partisanship, drives sharing of misinformation
item.description: But getting people to pay attention to news quality doesn’t seem to help much.

item.title: ~4,300 publicly reachable servers are posing a new DDoS hazard to the Internet
item.description: DDoS-for-hire services adopt new technique that amplifies attacks 37 fold.

item.title: FreeBSD kernel-mode WireGuard moves forward out-of-tree
item.description: Development has been moved to Donenfeld’s own zx2c4.com for the time being.

item.title: Amid panic over AstraZeneca vaccine, WHO urges countries to keep using it
item.description: COVID vaccines don’t prevent blood clots, which are common in the general population.

item.title: Intel hires Justin Long to mock Macs in throwback to 2000s “I’m a Mac” ads
item.description: “No one really games on a Mac.”

item.title: A severe weather outbreak is underway across the southern United States
item.description: When warm and cold air masses collide, bad things can happen.

item.title: Intel Rocket Lake-S desktop gaming CPUs are here
item.description: Rocket Lake-S looks like a solid gen-on-gen improvement—but not a Ryzen-killer.

item.title: Samsung Galaxy A52 is the follow-up to Samsung’s best-selling phone
item.description: The best model has a 120 Hz display, Snapdragon 750G for ~$510.

item.title: AT&T whines about Calif. net neutrality law as ISPs’ case appears doomed
item.description: Judge thoroughly rejected ISPs' arguments against Calif. law, transcript shows.

item.title: A Maya ambassador’s grave reveals his surprisingly difficult life
item.description: The grave offers a rare glimpse at the lives of high-ranking Mayan officials.

item.title: Study finds 3-ft distancing in schools is enough—but debate is far from over
item.description: New study had a firm conclusion on 3 feet, but rather shaky data.

item.title: The Queen of the Nürburgring, Sabine Schmitz, has died
item.description: A regular on Top Gear, the racing driver was loved by millions.

item.title: BMW’s big electric car push: Selling 2 million new EVs by 2025
item.description: The iX arrives next year, but expect “mid $80s” pricing for the big BEV.

item.title: Could we fuel our jets using our sewage?
item.description: The conversion is expensive, but it avoids a lot of landfill emissions.

item.title: Strange microbe “breathes” nitrates using a mitochondria-like symbiont
item.description: A relatively recent symbiosis is reminiscent of the ‘powerhouse of the cell.’

item.title: AMD Radeon RX 6700XT review: If another sold-out GPU falls in the forest…
item.description: Stop me if you’ve heard this one before: There’s a new GPU coming out, but…

item.title: I was a teenage Twitter hacker. Graham Ivan Clark gets 3-year sentence
item.description: Florida teen pleads guilty to attack that took over Twitter’s internal systems.

item.title: Google’s new Nest display wants to watch you while you sleep
item.description: There’s no camera—sleep tracking happens via a Soli radar chip.

item.title: Google undercuts Apple with new 15% revenue share for Play apps
item.description: Unlike Apple, cut applies to first $1 million regardless of total revenue.

item.title: Another self-driving startup got gobbled up by incumbents
item.description: Voyage tested a retirement-community taxi service but never went driverless.

item.title: Cricut backs off plan to add subscription fee to millions of devices [Updated]
item.description: Cricut’s not the first to pull this—and won’t be the last, unless regulators catch up.

item.title: Get a bonus $20 gift card when you buy a new Nintendo Switch Lite today
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on Sony’s WH-1000XM4, HyperX headsets, and more.

item.title: Mimecast says SolarWinds hackers breached its network and spied on customers
item.description: Mimecast-issued certificate used to connect to customers’ Microsoft 365 tenants.

item.title: Touch of gray: The Air Force can’t retire the Boeing 707
item.description: In this installment of SitRep, we look at the 707’s longevity as a military workhorse.

item.title: The 2021 Toyota Supra: We didn’t think they made them like this anymore
item.description: The 3.0 is the one to pick, especially after its 14 percent power bump for 2021.

item.title: $16 attack shows how easy carriers make it to intercept text messages
item.description: Reporter details problem in story titled, “A Hacker Got All My Texts for $16.”

item.title: Huawei plans to start charging patent fees to Samsung, Apple for each phone sold
item.description: Huawei expects to fetch between $1.2 and 1.3 billion in patent fees.

item.title: Nvidia accidentally releases driver to un-nerf cryptocurrency mining
item.description: Nvidia hobbled the RTX 3060’s mining abilities to reserve the card for gamers.

item.title: Qualcomm now owns Nuvia, aims new CPU design resources directly at Apple
item.description: Apple’s former chief CPU architect is now Qualcomm’s SVP of engineering.

item.title: Developers to update GTA Online to address poor load times after community fix
item.description: Rockstar acknowledges t0st’s patch fixes issue, then pays out a $10k bug bounty.

item.title: TikTok wants to keep tracking iPhone users with state-backed workaround
item.description: They want to keep tracking iPhone users with solution created by state-backed group.

item.title: Many Republicans are refusing COVID vaccines. Experts are trying to change that
item.description: Straight facts and no politics are what’s needed to increase vaccination.

item.title: In-kernel WireGuard is on its way to FreeBSD and the pfSense router
item.description: WireGuard probably won’t make it into 13.0-RELEASE, but 13.1 seems very likely.

item.title: NASA has begun a study of the SLS rocket’s affordability [Updated]
item.description: One issue up for grabs: Should work on the Exploration Upper Stage continue?

item.title: “Please someone help me.” FaceTime users bombarded with group call spam
item.description: Apple doesn’t provide tools that effectively ease a major headache for FaceTime users.

item.title: Report: Indian government is planning outright ban on cryptocurrency
item.description: The proposed bill would ban trading, mining, and even holding cryptocurrencies.

item.title: PA woman charged with using deepfakes to harass teenage cheerleaders
item.description: Specifically using deepfakes isn’t against state law, but harassment sure is.

item.title: AMD’s Epyc Milan offers double Intel Xeon’s datacenter performance
item.description: It’s hard to overstate how badly AMD is shaming Intel in the data center lately.

item.title: Volkswagen Group wants six new European battery factories by 2030
item.description: It’s moving to a single prismatic cell design in 2023 to drive down costs.

item.title: Marvel drops one last trailer for The Falcon and the Winter Soldier
item.description: “Symbols are nothing without the men and women that give them meaning.”

item.title: US claims seller of encrypted phones violated racketeering and drug laws
item.description: US: Company put “sophisticated encryption” on phones sold to drug traffickers.

item.title: How does the brain interpret computer languages?
item.description: Neuroscientists detect a distinct brain network that grows stronger with practice.

item.title: Apple pulls the plug on the HomePod
item.description: “We are focusing our efforts on HomePod mini,” the company says.

item.title: Judge rules $5 billion Google Chrome Incognito mode lawsuit can go forward
item.description: Lawsuit contends that “private” browsing mode should block Google’s web tracking.

item.title: Satellites detect volcanoes heating up before they blow
item.description: Subtle temperature changes can indicate growing eruption risk.

item.title: Justice League’s Snyder cut review: No longer Whedonesque—and all the better
item.description: Four years later, this film has gone from “acceptably subpar” to “Ars approved.”

item.title: Elon Musk formally declares himself Technoking of Tesla
item.description: Tesla CFO Zach Kirkhorn is now “Master of Coin,” Tesla says in SEC filing.

item.title: Xbox Wireless Headset review: $99 set with engineering wins, first-gen stumbles
item.description: Clever gimmicks, issues with sound, comfort make this an uneven Xbox debut.

item.title: Kia rolls out a new design philosophy for its next electric crossover
item.description: We’ll be seeing more of Kia’s “Opposites United” design in the coming years.

item.title: Panasonic to reduce Tesla reliance as battery tie-up evolves
item.description: Outgoing CEO steers company away from ‘one-legged’ dependence on US carmaker.

item.title: After Sunday’s launch, SpaceX is on the cusp of a historic reuse milestone
item.description: “For those that know rockets, this is a ridiculously hard thing."

item.title: The Ars Technica System Guide, spring 2021: Gaming edition
item.description: Supply shortages made building a gaming PC near-impossible—but you can buy one.
